_prev_prog_3.Description:
As a vital element of the Schreiber Foods, Logan Plant prevention program, Schreiber Foods has inaugurated a Process Safety Management Program as mandated by OSHA Standard 29 CFR 1910.119.  Schreiber Foods has implemented strict preventive maintenance and operating procedures in compliance with the Process Safety Management program. Additionally, the facility has developed an Emergency Response Plan where the release of ammonia is specially covered in the plan and contains all required actions in the event of a release of ammonia.
As part of the facility's prevention programs, emergency and operational training is conducted for employees and new hires.  Accidental release prevention, training and awareness are reinforced annually, and as operations at the facility dictates.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
SCHREIBER FOODS, INC  -  LOGAN, UTAH

This document has been prepared to document how Schreiber Foods complies with the requirements set forth under EPA's Chemical Accidental Prevention Provisions (40 CFR Part 68).  

This plan has been developed specifically to address the requirements applicable to the use of anhydrous ammonia at Schreiber Foods, Inc., located at 885 North 600 West, Logan, Utah. Each of the following sections provides a general overview of the requirements and defines the design attributes, documentation, and actions that are established to comply with those requirements.  In most instances, Schreiber Foods has already developed measures and systems that provide compliance with 40 CFR Part 68 rules as a result of other regulatory programs and requirements.  This document does not replicate that information but rather provides cross-references to the applicable existing documentation.  In those instances where information was developed specifically to comply with the Part 68 requirements, that information is contained in this document.

1.0      EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

1.1.    Corporate Commitment to Safety

Schreiber Foods is committed in providing to all employees a work environment that is free from recognized health and safety hazards.  Accordingly, our goal is achieving and sustaining a "Zero Accident Tolerance" through communication, information, and training.  To this end, we are dedicated to the concept that all employees receive the proper orientation and are provided with the means necessary to ensure the environment remains as safe and healthful as possible.

1.1.1     It is the policy of Schreiber Foods to:

1.1.1.1     Provide personnel with safe working conditions, proper tools, and personal protective equipment.

1.1.1.2     Comply with all federal, state, and local occupational health, safety, and environmental laws and regulations.

1.1.1.3     Provide and sustain a high level of commitment to ensure all employees have a safe and healthy work environment to work.

1.1.1.4     Ensure through training and corrective action when necessary, that all employees work in a safe manner.

1.1.1.5     Educate / train all employees in safe work practices, and ensure that each employee fully understands their job, equipment, techniques, and methods to reduce the risk to themselves and their co-workers.

1.1.1.6. Encourage all employees to "Think Safety", so that safety habits developed and practiced at work carry through to non-work related activities.

1.1.2.    Schreiber Foods? aim is to provide professional services efficiently as possible while minimizing the use of toxic materials where ever and whenever prudent.  In this effort our highest priority will be the proactive in pursuit of cost-effective process changes that reduce or eliminate the use and/or generation of hazardous toxics at the endpoint of service.  Where hazardous toxics cannot be eliminated, improving controls to handle these substances will be explored

and implemented wherever possible.

1.1.3.    Schreiber Foods has prepared a facility safety policy and procedure program specifically tailored for the facility. In addition, a Process Safety Management Program has also been established and implemented regarding the ammonia refrigeration system process. It is the responsibility of the designated facility personnel to carry out these programs.

1.1.4.    The first duty of Schreiber Foods employees is to exercise care in the performance of his/her work tasks to prevent an accident to him/herself, co-workers, the general public or equipment.  Safety-consciousness must take precedence over expedience, and is required as a condition of continued employment of all employees at all levels of the organization.

1.2.    Schreiber Foods Facility Description

Schreiber Foods, Inc, Logan location has two processes. The Logan Plant is responsible for the manufacturing of various cheese and dairy products. The Utah Distribution Center, (UDC) is responsible for the cold storage and distribution of the cheese and dairy products. The Logan facility is located in Logan, Utah and collectively employs approximately 511 personnel between the two processes.

1.2.1.    The substance regulated under the Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions (40 CFR 68) that is located on site, in various locations and quantities is anhydrous ammonia.

1.2.2.    Anhydrous ammonia is utilized on site for the "Refrigeration System". The ammonia is contained in various vessels, piping, condensers and evaporators used throughout the two ammonia refrigeration processes.  


1.3.    Worst Case Release Scenario

1.3.1.    As stipulated in EPA guidelines, 40 CFR Part 68.25(b)(1) the worst case release scenario was calculated and the results are on file at the Logan facility. 

1.4.    Alternate Case Release Scenario

1.4.1.    The alternative release scenario was also calculated according to the EPA guidelines and is on file at the facility. 

1.5.    Emergency Response Program

1.5.1.    Schre

iber Foods is equipped with an emergency notification system.  Evacuation plans are placed throughout the facility to inform personnel in an emergency relating to the accidental release of ammonia, or other emergencies that may be encountered.  There are specific procedures that all employees must follow in the event of release; which can be found in the Schreiber Foods Emergency Response Plan.  These procedures include evacuation of personnel, notification of authorities and actions to be taken to stop, or mitigate the emergency if it is safe to do so.

1.5.2.    Logan Plant and UDC personnel have received emergency response training as outlined in OSHA Standard 29 CFR 1910.120.

1.5.3.    The Logan City Fire Department has visited the facility to review the process operations, safety systems and discussed emergency response coordination.
